table.name: syst_access_account_instance_assocs
table.remarks: Associates access accounts with the instances for which they are allowed to authenticate to. Note that being able to authenticate to an instance is not the same as having authorized rights within the instance; authorization is handled by the instance directly.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: access_account_id
column.remarks: The access account which is being granted authentication rights to the given instance.

column.name: credential_type_id
column.remarks: Allows a specific kind of credential to be used to authenticate the access account to the instance. Typically this is to control the ability to connect as a user or using API tokens.

column.name: instance_id
column.remarks: The identity of the instance to which authentication rights is being granted.

column.name: access_granted
column.remarks: The timestamp at which access to the instance was granted and active. If the access did not require the access invitation process, this value will typically reflect the creation timestamp of the record. If the invitation was required, it will reflect the time when the access account holder actually accepted the invitation to access the instance.

column.name: invitation_issued
column.remarks:
When inviting unowned, independent access accounts such as might be used by an external bookkeeper, the grant of access by the instance owner is not immediately effective but must also be approved by the access account holder being granted access. The timestamp in this column indicates when the invitation to connect to the instance was issued.
If the value in this column is null, the assumption is that no invitation was required to grant the access to the access account.

column.name: invitation_expires
column.remarks: The timestamp at which the invitation to access a given instance expires.

column.name: invitation_declined
column.remarks: The timestamp at which the access account holder explicitly declined the invitation to access the given instance.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_access_accounts
table.remarks: Contains the known login accounts which are used solely for the purpose of authentication of users. Authorization is handled on a per-instance basis within the application.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: Provides a user visible name for display purposes only. This field is not unique and may not be used as a key.

column.name: owning_owner_id
column.remarks:
Associates the access account with a specific owner. This allows for access accounts which are identified and managed exclusively by a given owner.
When this field is NULL, the assumption is that it's an independent access account. An independent access account may be used, for example, by third party accountants that need to access the instances of different owners.

column.name: allow_global_logins
column.remarks:
When true, allows an access account to log into the system without having an owner or instance specified in the login process. This use case supports access accounts which are independently managed, such as might be the case for external bookkeepers. When false, the access account is more tightly bound to a specific owner and so only a specific owner and instances should be evaluated at login time.
The need for this distinction arises when considering logins for access account holders such as customers or vendors. In these cases access to the owner's environment should appear to be unique, but they may use the same identifier as used for a different, but unrelated, owner. In this case you have multiple access accounts with possibly the same identifier; to resolve the conflict, it is required therefore to know which owner or instance the access accounts holder is trying to access. In the allow global case we can just ask the account holder but in the disallow global case we need to know it in advance.

column.name: access_account_state_id
column.remarks: The current life-cycle state of the access account.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_applications
table.remarks: Describes the known applications which is managed by the global database and authentication infrastructure.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_credentials
table.remarks: Hosts the credentials by which a user or external system will prove its identity. Note that not all credential types are available for authentication with all identity types.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: access_account_id
column.remarks: The access account for which the credential is to be used.

column.name: credential_type_id
column.remarks: The kind of credential that the record represents. Note that the behavior and use cases of the credential may have specific processing and handling requirements based on the functional type of the credential type.

column.name: credential_for_identity_id
column.remarks:
When an access account identity is created for either identity validation or access account recovery, a single use identity is created as well as a single use credential. In this specific case, the one time use credential and the one time use identity are linked. This is especially important in recovery scenarios to ensure that only the correct recovery communication can recover the account. This field identifies the which identity is associated with the credential.
For regular use identities, there are no special credential requirements that would be needed to for a link and the value in this column should be null.

column.name: credential_data
column.remarks: The actual data which supports verifying the presented identity in relation to the access account.

column.name: last_updated
column.remarks: For credential types where rules regarding updating may apply, such as common passwords, this column indicates when the credential was last updated (timestamp of last password change, for example). This field is explicitly not for dating trivial or administrative changes which don't actually materially change the credential data; please consult the appropriate diagnostic fields for those use cases.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_enum_functional_types
table.remarks: For those enumerations requiring functional type designation, this table defines the available types and persists related metadata. Note that not all enumerations require functional types.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A non-unique/non-key value used to display to users and external parties where uniqueness is less of a concern than specific end user presentation.

column.name: enum_id
column.remarks: A reference to the owning enumeration of the functional type.

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks: A default description of the specific functional type and its use cases within the enumeration which is identitied as the parent.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A custom, user suppplied description of the functional type which will be preferred over the syst_description field if set to a not null value.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_enum_values
table.remarks: The list of values provided by an enumeration as well as related behavioral and informational metadata.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A non-unique/non-key value used to display to users and external parties where uniqueness is less of a concern than specific end user presentation.

column.name: enum_id
column.remarks: The enumeration record with which the value is associated.

column.name: functional_type_id
column.remarks: If the enumeration requires a functional type, this column references the functional type associated with the enumeration value record. Note that not all enumerations require functional types. If syst_enum_functional_types records exist for an enumeration, then this column will be required for any values of that enumeration; if there are no functional types defined for an enumeration, the this column must remain NULL.

column.name: enum_default
column.remarks:
If true, indicates that this value is the default selection from all values defined for the enumerations. If false then the value record has no special significance relative to defaulting.
Note that if a record is inserted or updated in this table with enum_default set true, and another record already exists for the enumeration with its enum_default set true, the newly inserted/updated record will take precedence and the value record previously set to be default will have its enum_default setting set to false.

column.name: functional_type_default
column.remarks:
If true, the value record is the default selection for any of a specific fucntional type. This is helpful in situations where a progression of state is automatically processed by the system and the state is represented by an enumeration. In cases where there are no functional types, this value should simply remain false.
Note that if a record is inserted or updated in this table with its functional_type_default set true, and another record already exists for the enumeration/functional type combination with its functional_type_default set true, the newly inserted/updated record will take precedence and the value record previously set to be default will have its functional_type_default setting set to false.

column.name: syst_defined
column.remarks: If true, indicates that the value was created by the system or system installation process. A false value indicates that the record was user created.

column.name: user_maintainable
column.remarks: If true, the user may maintain the value including setting user_options or even setting the record inactive/deleting it. If false, the value record is required by the system for correct operation. The user_description and user_options columns are always available for user maintenance regardless of this setting.

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks: A system default description describing the value and its use cases within the enumeration.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A custom user defined description which overrides the syst_description value where it would otherwise be used. If this column is set NULL the syst_description value will be used.

column.name: sort_order
column.remarks: Indicates the sort ordering of the particular value record with the lowest value sorting first. When a value record for an enumeration is inserted or updated and this column is being set to a value which equals another enumeration value record for the same enumeration, the system assumes that the new record is being set to precede the existing record and it will be set to sort after the newly inserted/updated enumeration value.

column.name: syst_options
column.remarks: Extended options and metadata which describe the behavior and meaning of the specific value within the enumeration. The owning syst_enums record's default_syst_options column will indicate what syst_options are required or available and establishes default values for them.

column.name: user_options
column.remarks: Extended user defined options, similar to syst_options, but for the purpose of driving custom functionality.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_enums
table.remarks: Enumerates the enumerations known to the system along with additional metadata useful in applying them appropriately.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks:
A default description of the enumeration which might include details such as how the enumeration is used and what kind of functionality might be impacted by choosing specific enumeration values.
Note that users should not change this value. For custom descriptions, use the msbms_syst_data.syst_enums.user_description field instead.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A user defined description of the enumeration to support custom user documentation of the purpose and function of the enumeration.

column.name: feature_id
column.remarks: A reference to the specific feature of which the enumeration is considered to be part. This reference is chiefly used to determine where in the configuration options the enumeration should appear.

column.name: syst_defined
column.remarks: If true, this value indicates that the enumeration is considered part of the application. Often times, system enumerations are manageable by users, but the existence of the enumeration in the system is assumed to exist by the application. If false, the assumption is that the enumeration was created by users and supports custom user functionality.

column.name: user_maintainable
column.remarks: When true, this column indicates that the enumeration is user maintainable; this might include the ability to add, edit, or remove enumeration values. When false, the enumeration is strictly system managed for any functional purpose. Note that the value of this column doesn't effect the ability to set a user_description value; the ability to set custom descriptions is always available for any properly authorized user.

column.name: default_syst_options
column.remarks: Establishes the expected extended system options along with default values if applicable. Note that this setting is used to both validate and set defaults in the syst_enum_values.syst_options column.

column.name: default_user_options
column.remarks: Allows a user to set the definition of syst_enum_values.user_options values and provide defaults for those values if appropriate.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_feature_enum_assigns
table.remarks: A join table which allows application enumerations to be associated with various application features. This is a many-to-many relationship. The expectation is that this association will be used in organizing certain configuration or permissioning displays into a tree-like structure.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: feature_map_id
column.remarks: Identifies the feature mapping record to which the relation record is being associated.

column.name: enum_id
column.remarks: Identifies the enumeration record which is being associated with the feature.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_feature_map
table.remarks: A map organizing the application's features into a tree-like structure. This is principally a documentation tool, but is also useful for features such as driving nested directories to aide users in navigating forms or configurations.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: external_name
column.remarks: A non-unique/non-key value used to display to users and external parties where uniqueness is less of a concern than specific end user presentation.

column.name: feature_map_level_id
column.remarks: Indicates to which level this mapping entry pertains. The mapping level will play a part in determining whether or not the mapping entry is able to be directly associated with specific features or if the mapping entry is just a container for other mapping entries.

column.name: parent_feature_map_id
column.remarks: Indicates of which mapping entry the current entry is a child, if it is a child of any entry. If this column is NULL, the mapping entry sits at the top/ root level of the hierarchy. This series of parent/child relationships between mapping entries establishes a tree structure for organizing system features.

column.name: system_defined
column.remarks: If true, indicates that the record was added by the standard system installation process. If false, the feature map level was user defined.

column.name: user_maintainable
column.remarks: If true, users may make modifications to the record including the possibility of deleting the record. If false, the user may only make minimal modifications to columns designated as user columns (i.e. user_description).

column.name: displayable
column.remarks: If true, the feature map record may appear in queried results for the application. If false, the feature map record will only be available if the user explicitly asks for hidden feature map records. Note that this field is user maintainable even when the user_maintainable column is false.

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks: A standard description of the mapping value suitable for display to application users.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A user customizable description which, if not NULL, will be used to override the text in syst_description.

column.name: sort_order
column.remarks: In user display contexts, indicates the sort relative to other records of the same level and grouping. Sorting is done on a lowest value first.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_feature_map_levels
table.remarks: Defines the available levels of hierarchy of the features map. Records in this table also determine whether or not individual features may be assigned at the level in question.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: functional_type
column.remarks:
Defines the system recognized types which can alter processing.
* assignable: Individual features may be mapped to syst_feature_map record assigned to a level of this functional type.
* nonassignable: When a syst_feature_map record is assigned to a level of this functional type, the syst_feature_map record may not be directly associated with individual features. The level is considered to be an intermediate node for grouping other, lower levels.

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks: A description of the level, its purpose in the hierarchy, and other useful information deemed relevant.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A user defined override of the syst_description text. If this column is not null, it will override the system defined text at times that the description would be visible to application users.

column.name: system_defined
column.remarks: If true, indicates that the record was added by the standard system installation process. If false, the feature map level was user defined.

column.name: user_maintainable
column.remarks: If true, users may make modifications to the record including the possibility of deleting the record. If false, the user may only make minimal modifications to columns designated as user columns (i.e. user_description).

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_feature_relation_assigns
table.remarks: A join table which allows application relations to be associated with various application features. This is a many-to-many relationship. The expectation is that this association will be used in organizing certain configuration or permissioning displays into a tree-like structure.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: feature_map_id
column.remarks: Identifies the feature mapping record to which the relation record is being associated.

column.name: relation_id
column.remarks: Identifies the relation record which is being associated with the feature.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_feature_setting_assigns
table.remarks: A join table which allows application settings to be associated with various application features. This is a many-to-many relationship. The expectation is that this association will be used in organizing certain configuration or permissioning displays into a tree-like structure.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: feature_map_id
column.remarks: Identifies the feature mapping record to which the relation record is being associated.

column.name: setting_id
column.remarks: Identifies the settings record which is being associated with the feature.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_identities
table.remarks: The identities with which access accounts are identified to the system. The most common example of an identity would be a user name such as an email address.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: access_account_id
column.remarks: The ID of the access account to be identified the identifier record.

column.name: identity_type_id
column.remarks: The kind of identifier being described by the record. Note that this value influences the kind of credentials that can be used to complete the authentication process.

column.name: identifier
column.remarks: The actual identifier which identifies a user or system to the system.

column.name: validated
column.remarks: The timestamp at which the identity was validated for use. Depending on the requirements of the identity functional type, the timestamp here may be set as the time of the identity creation or it may set when the access account holder actually makes a formal verification. A null value here indicates that the identity is not validated by the access account holder and is not able to be used for authentication to the system.

column.name: validates_identity_id
column.remarks: Each identity requiring validation will require its own validation. Since validation requests are also single use identities, we need to know which permanent identifier is being validate. This column points to the identifier that is being validated. When the current identifier is not being used for validation, this field is null.

column.name: validation_requested
column.remarks: The timestamp on which the validation request was issued to the access account holder. This value will be null if the identity did not require validation.

column.name: validation_expires
column.remarks: The timetstamp at which a required validation request will expire. When an identity validation is not required, this column will be null.

column.name: primary_contact
column.remarks: Indicates that the identity is also used for communicating with the access account holder. This value may only be true if the identity_type_id value is of functional type 'email'.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_instances
table.remarks: Defines known application instances and provides their configuration settings.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: application_id
column.remarks: Indicates an instance of which application is being described by the record.

column.name: instance_type_id
column.remarks: Indicates the type of the instance. This can designate instances as being production or non-production, or make other functional differences between instances created for different reasons based on the assigned instance type.

column.name: instance_state_id
column.remarks: Establishes the current life-cycle state of the instance record. This can determine functionality such as if the instance is usable, visible, or if it may be purged from the database completely.

column.name: owner_id
column.remarks: Identifies the owner of the instance. The owner is the entity which commissioned the instance and is the "user" of the instance. Owners have nominal management rights over their instances, such as which access accounts and which credential types are allowed to be used to authenticate to the owner's instances.

column.name: dbserver_name
column.remarks: References a database server found in the msbms_startup_options.toml file. While this file may override certain defaults set for the server in that file, we need to use the references in that file to know where we should connect.

column.name: db_app_context_pool_size
column.remarks: The number of pooled database connections available to the application access context. The application will checkout connections from the pool as needed and otherwise queue requests as necessary (within limits).

column.name: db_api_context_pool_size
column.remarks: The number of pooled database connections available to the API access context. The application will checkout connections from the pool as needed and otherwise queue requests as necessary (within limits).

column.name: instance_code
column.remarks: A randomly generated sequence of bytes used in instance database connection authentication. Note that this value, while random, should be no fewer than 32 bytes long.

column.name: owning_instance_id
column.remarks: In some cases, an instance is considered subordinate to another instance. For example, consider a production environment and a related sandbox environment. The existence of the sandbox doesn't have real meaning without being associated with some sort of production instance where the real work is performed. This kind of association becomes clearer in SaaS environments where a primary instance is contracted for, but other supporting instances, such as a sandbox, should follow certain account related actions of the primary.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_owners
table.remarks: Identifies instance owners. Instance owners are typically the clients which have commissioned the use of an application instance.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record, suitable for use in user interactions

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_relations
table.remarks: A list of the application tables and associated metadata that is not normally part of the table definition kept in the catalog. This includes categorization by the feature type and association with forms and operations that may make use of the relation. Finally, this serves to associate enum values to the relations to which they pertain.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: schema_name
column.remarks: The schema name where the record's table resides.

column.name: table_name
column.remarks: The name of the relation that is the subject of the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

column.name: diag_row_version
column.remarks: The current version of the row. The value here indicates how many actual data changes have been made to the row. If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.

table.name: syst_settings
table.remarks: Configuration data which establishes application behaviors, defaults, and provides a reference center to interested application functionality.

column.name: id
column.remarks: The record's primary key. The definitive identifier of the record in the system.

column.name: internal_name
column.remarks: A candidate key useful for programmatic references to individual records.

column.name: display_name
column.remarks: A friendly name and candidate key for the record suitable for use in user interfaces.

column.name: syst_description
column.remarks: A text describing the meaning and use of the specific record.

column.name: user_description
column.remarks: A user customizable override of the system description text. When the value in this column is not NULL, this text will be displayed to users in preference to the description found in syst_description.

column.name: config_flag
column.remarks: A boolean configuration point.

column.name: config_integer
column.remarks: An integer configuration point

column.name: config_decimal
column.remarks: An decimal configuration point (not floating point).

column.name: config_interval
column.remarks: An interval configuration point.

column.name: config_date
column.remarks: A date configuation point.

column.name: config_time
column.remarks: A time configuration point (without time zone).

column.name: config_timestamp
column.remarks: A full datetime configuration point including time zone.

column.name: config_json
column.remarks: A JSON configuration point. Note that duplicate keys at the same level are not allowed.

column.name: config_text
column.remarks: A text configuration point.

column.name: config_uuid
column.remarks: A UUID configuration point.

column.name: config_blob
column.remarks: A binary configuration point.

column.name: diag_timestamp_created
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which created the record started.

column.name: diag_role_created
column.remarks: The database role which created the record.

column.name: diag_timestamp_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time when the transaction which modified the record started. This field will be the same as diag_timestamp_created for inserted records.

column.name: diag_wallclock_modified
column.remarks: The database server date/time at the moment the record was actually modified. For long running transactions this time may be significantly later than the value of diag_timestamp_modified.

column.name: diag_role_modified
column.remarks: The database role which modified the record.

If an update of the row leaves all data fields the same, disregarding the updates to the diag_* columns, the row version is not updated, nor are any updates made to the other diag_* columns other than diag_update_count.

column.name: diag_update_count
column.remarks: Records the number of times the record has been updated regardless as to if the update actually changed any data. In this way needless or redundant record updates can be found. This row starts at 0 and therefore may be the same as the diag_row_version - 1.
